  The Early Show | CBS Evening News | 48 Hours
    | 60 Minutes | The Saturday Early Show | CBS Sunday
    Morning | Face The
    Nation 















Hi everyone. 
 
This is Harry Smith filling in for Katie.
 
It has been nine days since Don Imus made the inflammatory
  on-air comments about the Rutgers women’s
  basketball team and now he has been fired by CBS. His career might be in dire
  straits, but he did get a hint of redemption from the young basketball players,
  who have accepted his apology. Could all this fury perhaps lead to a more
  civil tone in American media? Nancy Cordes will have the story.
 
We’ll also give you an update on New Jersey
  Gov. Jon Corzine, who was badly injured in a car crash on the Garden State Parkway
  while en route to mediating the meeting between Imus and the women’s
  basketball team. 
 
Pakistan’s
  president Pervez Musharraf is facing his harshest criticism since 9/11 for
  not doing more to fight terrorism. Despite that the Taliban threat seems to
  be growing on both sides of his country’s border with Afghanistan, Musharraf defends
  his efforts. Our chief foreign correspondent Lara Logan sat down with
  Musharraf and tonight we’ll share her interview with you. (And later
  you’ll be able to see the whole interview online at CBSNews.com.)
 
Back in America, Jim Axelrod will report
  on one of the frontrunners for the GOP presidential nomination: Mitt Romney. The
  former Massachusetts governor has worked
  hard to portray himself as a Washington
  outsider and has had great success fundraising. But will voters warm up to
  his religion?
 
Sixty years ago this Sunday, Jackie Robinson broke
  baseball’s color barrier. Tonight, Cynthia Bowers will introduce you to
  a man who, nearly 50 years ago, wrote letters of admiration to Jackie. What’s
  amazing: Jackie wrote back. We will share some of his correspondence with
  you. 
 
Finally, Steve Hartman will have for Assignment
  America the story of Arnold Blume, a man who may be the country’s
  oldest substitute teacher. 
 
I hope you’ll join us and have a great weekend.
 




Katie Couric
CouricandCo@cbs.com
